Posts.Content: I'm guessing it might take a while for PSA to get lower. Also the larger the prostate, the more PSA can be created by the prostate. If you have a large prostate it might not go lower.
Posts.Title: Worried - Enlarged Prostate

Posts.Content: Welcome. Your PSA may be high for your age but not super high. You are not too young to have BPH. PSA could be elevated from an infection or inflammation, etc. IF you had cancer the symptoms would be a negative. Many prostate cancers grow slowly. A biopsy is usually an outpatient procedure where spring-loaded needed go into the prostate for samples. There is a free PSA test and a PHI blood work that might be informative. Good luck with your situation.

Posts.Title: 15 month Update - PSA moved from .02 to .06. Concerned...

Posts.Content: Welcome. Getting the info 2nd or 3rd hand , its difficult to know exactly the situation. If he needs radiation than you should be concerned. It may be very aggressive prostate cancer or it might have been spread to lymph nodes or seminal vesicles or beyond the prostate margins. Prostate cancer sometimes grows slowly and many patients live for a long time. Questions are his age, Gleason Score, PSA number and the specific info from the doctor. The patient should obtain a copy of pathology report and operation report. Good luck to you both.

Posts.Content: The Gleason 4+3 of 7 is intermediate prostate cancer, with a Gleason of 10 being the most aggressive. I don't understand how the doctor knows the cancer cells escaped. Maybe he had prostate margins that were postive for cancer. Only the doctor can explain. Radiation in conjunction with surgery sometimes works for a very long time but not always.

Posts.Title: radiation after prostate removal

Posts.Content: Welcome. If I understand you have had a course of antibiotic and are not currently taking testosterone. PSA can rise from inflammation, infection and prostate cancer. You might consider other blood tests such as Free PSA (higher is better.) or PCA3. Also the Digital Rectal Exam may find nodules on prostate, if there are any. Another option to consider later is a biopsy where spring loaded needles are shot into the prostate through the rectum. (It stung a bit in my case.Outpatient test.) It is unlikely that headache is related. An important factor is your age. What is it? Anyway good luck on any further testing.

I can't speak for Kaiser but urologists schedule biopsies as outpatient procedures and they are somewhat unpleasant. So you would not get a biopsy at the first urologist appointment. Nothing is likely to happen real fast to you. IF you did have prostate cancer, you are very likely to live for many years.

Posts.Content: Welcome. You have very informed questions to ask, but might be beyond the knowledge or interest of some urologists. Also many appointments are 15 minutes or less. If you are seeking the most sophisticated urologist, you might just skip the local uro and go to Johns Hopkins in Baltimore or some other major center. Most local urologists do 12 core biopsies after an ultrasound. A nice thing about the local uro was that I could hand carry my records and biopsy slides to another doctor for 2nd opinion. My urologist did not have anyone call to tell me I had cancer, I was told on a followup 2 weeks later. Good luck.

Posts.Title: radiation after prostate removal

Posts.Content: Welcome. Getting the info 2nd or 3rd hand , its difficult to know exactly the situation. If he needs radiation than you should be concerned. It may be very aggressive prostate cancer or it might have been spread to lymph nodes or seminal vesicles or beyond the prostate margins. Prostate cancer sometimes grows slowly and many patients live for a long time. Questions are his age, Gleason Score, PSA number and the specific info from the doctor. The patient should obtain a copy of pathology report and operation report. Good luck to you both.

Posts.Content: Welcome. You have very informed questions to ask, but might be beyond the knowledge or interest of some urologists. Also many appointments are 15 minutes or less. If you are seeking the most sophisticated urologist, you might just skip the local uro and go to Johns Hopkins in Baltimore or some other major center. Most local urologists do 12 core biopsies after an ultrasound. A nice thing about the local uro was that I could hand carry my records and biopsy slides to another doctor for 2nd opinion. My urologist did not have anyone call to tell me I had cancer, I was told on a followup 2 weeks later. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Welcome. Your PSA may be high for your age but not super high. You are not too young to have BPH. PSA could be elevated from an infection or inflammation, etc. IF you had cancer the symptoms would be a negative. Many prostate cancers grow slowly. A biopsy is usually an outpatient procedure where spring-loaded needed go into the prostate for samples. There is a free PSA test and a PHI blood work that might be informative. Good luck with your situation.

Posts.Title: Not diagnosed but nervous

Posts.Content: Welcome. If I understand you have had a course of antibiotic and are not currently taking testosterone. PSA can rise from inflammation, infection and prostate cancer. You might consider other blood tests such as Free PSA (higher is better.) or PCA3. Also the Digital Rectal Exam may find nodules on prostate, if there are any. Another option to consider later is a biopsy where spring loaded needles are shot into the prostate through the rectum. (It stung a bit in my case.Outpatient test.) It is unlikely that headache is related. An important factor is your age. What is it? Anyway good luck on any further testing.

Posts.Content: Hey again. I would try to take it one day at a time. And you don't know if you have it. There are many gradations of prostate cancer, most of which are slow growing. I can't speak for Kaiser but urologists schedule biopsies as outpatient procedures and they are somewhat unpleasant. So you would not get a biopsy at the first urologist appointment. Nothing is likely to happen real fast to you. IF you did have prostate cancer, you are very likely to live for many years.

Posts.Title: Diet

Posts.Content: Welcome. If I understand you have had a course of antibiotic and are not currently taking testosterone. PSA can rise from inflammation, infection and prostate cancer. You might consider other blood tests such as Free PSA (higher is better.) or PCA3. Also the Digital Rectal Exam may find nodules on prostate, if there are any. Another option to consider later is a biopsy where spring loaded needles are shot into the prostate through the rectum. (It stung a bit in my case.Outpatient test.) It is unlikely that headache is related. An important factor is your age. What is it? Anyway good luck on any further testing.

Posts.Content: Bee man, Nadir plus 2.0 means 2ng more than the lowest recorded PSA . For example, if nadir is 0.5, then recurrence would be suspected at 2.5 .If nadir is 1.1, then recurrence suspected at 3.1 . If nadir was 2.1, recurrence suspected at 4.1 .

Posts.Title: What can I expect after 18 beam Radiation Treatments and should I get regular PSA tes

Posts.Content: Hello. PSA is generated by prostate tissue. The bigger the prostate, the more the expected PSA. There is a concept of PSA density, PSA divided by prostate size. A smaller prostate would expect a smaller PSA. There is a blood test called FreePSA ( higher is better on this test.) You might ask for a FreePSA blood test next time you get a PSA test. I would try to obtain a FreePSA blood test before you decide what if anything to do next. Good luck.

Posts.Title: 45 yrs old, PSA=2.45...neep a pep talk

Posts.Content: Sorry about the results. Sounds like an aggressive cancer. What was his PSA? That is also a determinant of the prognosis. A lot of ethical doctors will not operate on a patient over the age of 70 because of risks and side effects. Radiation and or hormone therapy (androgen deprivation therapry) are options. A lot of Gleason 9 patients live for quite a number of years following radiation or hormone treatment. There are also a lot of new and expensive meds coming along. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: Urgent Advice Needed. Gleason 9

Posts.Content: I never heard about sodium bicarb therapy. There are some therapies to try for an alkaline ph balance but they are marginal therapies. Hormone therapy / androgen deprivation therapy are mainstays of treatment. This sometimes works for years. Chemo is only used usually if hormone therapy fails, and is often not super effective for prostate cancer. He should consult with a radiation oncologist and maybe an oncologist in addition to the urologist he saw.
Posts.Title: Urgent Advice Needed. Gleason 9

Posts.Content: I believe Dr Walsh believed in HT later, rather than sooner. So there is some disagreement among doctors about when to start HT. A reason is that HT only works on hormone sensitive Prostate cancer. It doesn't work on hormone insensitive cancer. The CHAARTED trial showed significant survival benefit for those on HT plus chemo, the trial may have required metastasis as a criteria. I would lean towards the wisdom of a good oncologist vs. a urologist. Good luck.

Posts.Title: What lies ahead

Posts.Content: If you only have one core with Gleason 6, Active Surveillance is reasonable. You are unlikely to die from a Gleason 6. You could start on AS and switch to treatment at a later time. Another option is Focal Ablation where they try to ablate the tiny tumor and leave the rest of prostate alone. Focal Ablation is only done in a limited number of centers in the USA. Hormone Therapy, including estrogen DES, is not considered a cure. Adding ADT to Active Surveillance would be an unusual path. You might want to see the videos from Dr. Charles Meyers on Wordpress. Meyers does not take insurance. He has some patients on Avodart, statins and metformin. You have plenty of time to reasearch the topics. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Bone Mets--Who has them?

Posts.Content: Sean, the Gleason score has a primary number added to a secondary number to give the total Gleason number. Most prostate cancers diagnosed now have a Gleason total of 6 to 10. 3+3 =6 for example would be non-aggressive cancer that might not require treatment. A Gleason total of 10 is very aggressive cancer. Good luck to you both.

Posts.Title: Bone Mets--Who has them?

Posts.Content: Welcome. You seem to know the basic questions. If husband has 1 or 2 small cores of Gleason 6, he might qualify for active surveillance or possibly focal ablation. If he has more extensive Gleason 6 he may be facing treatment. Radiation and surgery are the main treatments. The urologist will probably offer treatment suggestions. Does this urologist do surgeries? Does he recommend a radiation oncologist? Is Active Surveillance possible? Can the patient obtain biopsy slides for 2nd opinion? Good luck with the pathology report that will clarify the options.

Posts.Content: Twenty years ago in Europe, PSA testing was not as common as it is now. More patients were diagnosed via DRE findings or after symptoms developed . Scanning and testing were not as sophisticated. AS protocols were not sophisticated. New treatments were not available. So I think things may have improved from when the study began.

Posts.Content: My biopsy in 2010 cost 280 dollars plus another 330 for the pathologist but I got the insurance group rate for an independent urology group, not a hospital. (Hosptials may charge more.) My co-pay was onlly $80 or so, including the pathologist. The price might be negotiable if you do not have insurance. The pain was not real bad but I had somebody drive me home just in case. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Anyone know of Cancer Center that will remove prostate in spite of bone metastasis?

Posts.Content: Hi. After radiation the standard for recurrence is nadir + 2 . Not sure if that is the standard for you since you also had hormone treatment. And sometimes the PSA does not move in a straight line after radiation at first. If .2 is your nadir, than 2.2 might be recurrence.Sometimes it does require interpretation. For example, your nadir might have been influenced by the hormone injection. The doubling time is important if it continues since PSA will hit new heights in the future sooner. Good luck.

Posts.Title: PSA Result or Doubling Time

Posts.Content: I don't think you need to be too concerned. The doctor sounds reasonable. Low free PSA can be bad, if I remember, and yours is not low. Normal and Abnormal Percent-Free PSA Typically, men have a percent-free PSA above 25%. Between 10% and 25% is considered an intermediate range and below 10% is considered to be low. However, a low percent-free PSA, even coupled with a high absolute PSA level (the raw number that you were told is your PSA number), does not necessarily mean you have prostate cancer. Only a biopsy can definitively diagnose prostate cancer. The digital rectal exam, DRE, can feel nodules on the prostate. You could try an antibiotic to see how that affects PSA. I'm thinking your PSA is not that alarming. You might track it periodically to see how it progresses, like on a graph, over time. There is also a new prostate blood test just developed that is more conclusive: Prostate Health Index (phi) Prostate cancer is often slow growing and affects older men the most. Good luck.

Posts.Title: It's Official - Zero Club

Posts.Content: Welcome. Surgery often will successfully treat the cancer. There are sexual and urinary risks to surgery. Radiation as primary treatment might work but you would be exposed to radiation at a young age. Androgen deprivation / hormone therapy is used mostly for aggressive cancer or if the primary treatment is not successful. Chemo style poisons are only used much later in the process if there is treatment failure. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Omega 3 and PC

Posts.Content: With an original PSA of 16, it is quite likely that there were micrometastases before radiation began. Radiation would not force cancer out of the prostate. Some experts diagnosis recurrence as nadir PSA +2 , the lowest PSA rising by 2. Some patients respond to hormone therapy such as Lupron for years. It varies a lot. Provenge is an excellent medicine. The sooner it is used, the more effective it will be in extending life. Medicare covers it I believe. The low extension of life in studies was due to the fact that the men in the studies were in later stages of the disease. Good luck to you and your father.

Posts.Title: Help with which pads to buy

Posts.Content: Lupron is a big money maker for US urologists. Uro surgeons are providing a systemic treatment partly because it is so profitable. Some oncologists also might offer Lupron. Insurance companies sometimes limit the allowable charge as does Medicare for those over 65. Good luck finding a better deal.

Posts.Title: New to this, Recently diagnosed with Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Some doctors like Walsh think that it doesn't matter when a patient starts HT. He prefers to wait until later. He posits that HT will not work on androgen insensitive cancer cells. Early treatment will tend to keep PSA low in the short term. If it were me, I would take it sooner. Saw a recent link that Quinine may extend the period that HT is effective. I think I read 2 years is average effect but that varies a lot. Estrogen may minimize side effects of HT. Some patients have taken estrogen instead of Lupron or other injections. That's all I know. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Alternatives to HT

Posts.Content: Welcome. Most patients have an increase in PSA when hormone therapy begins to fail. Your father in law may be an exception. A bone scan, if available, might reveal something. Here options include changes to hormone therapy, spot radiation, expensive new drugs, clinical trials, chemotherapy. Good luck.

Posts.Title: My dad's prostate cancer is back. Now what?

Posts.Content: Welcome. Johns Hopkins has a good reputation. Any large hospital / center should be able to diagnose. Prostate cancer is typically diagnosed with a biopsy including ultrasound. (Needles through the rectum into prostate for samples. Outpatient procedure.) Guessing a contrast CT scan could isolate the bladder on film. You might try to obtain a copy of any medical records wherever you are treated. Good luck getting a diagnosis. Patients with prostate cancer that has not metastasized usually live for quite a number of years, if treated. P.S. What are his age and PSA number?

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with cancer

Posts.Content: Welcome. Sorry to hear about the diagnosis. There is no rush in your case. You should live more than 10 years without treatment. Your choices are surgery or radiation. Radiation can be seed insertion or many sessions with external beam radiation. Try to calm down and research the subject. Surgery has the risks of sexual and urinary side effects. Radiation risks are not as big. Good luck making a decision.

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed.need help! Am i a candidate for robotic surgery?

Posts.Content: Hello. His worst core samples showed Gleason 8 but the report mentioned Gleason 7. People usually catorgorize PC by the worst cores, so he would be Gleason 8 IMO. A wait of 6-10 weeks after biopsy is not unusual before treatment begins. Cancer sometimes escapes before treatment, scans can sometimes detect but not always. If you get a second opinion they will need his urological medical records and probably biopsy slides so that might be something you may have to collect. Long term survival is good after treatment and new treatments are coming. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Advice. Thoughts. Diagnosed with Prostate Cancer at 52 Gleason Score of 6,7 and 8..

Posts.Content: Welcome. What country are you from"? Patients in your fathers condition would usually be on more than Casodex, I'm thinking. Typically they would take Lupron or a similar treatment to lower testosterone. This is given by injection. Life expectancy might depend on how the person responds to low testosterone environment from the injections. It varies. There are also some other treatments such as Provenge immunotherapy , Zytiga, Xtandi and chemo. Some of these are super expensive in USA. Good luck to you both.

Posts.Title: Increasing PSA after surgery and hormone theraphy

Posts.Content: Welcome. Do you know his Gleason score? The chance of PSA rise from infection is small but not impossible. Maybe they should have tested PSA again to verify it. I am concerned about the PSA Doubling Time. There are calculators that compute the doubling time on the internet. If the PSA goes down after his hormone shot, then the PSA rise was from cancer. But not every patient responds to the hormone shot. Continued response to the hormone therapy would be good and extend his life if he has recurrence. There are a lot of new approved drugs and drugs in the pipeline. Good luck to you both.

Since you are young, surgery might be all right except for possible side effects. Radiation might have less side effects. But you are exposed to radiation. Freezing has more of a chance of return of the cancer by a slight margin. Good luck making the tough decision.

Posts.Title: biopsy result yesterday ... I have prostate cancer at 40 years old. Need advices

Posts.Content: Hello. His worst core samples showed Gleason 8 but the report mentioned Gleason 7. People usually catorgorize PC by the worst cores, so he would be Gleason 8 IMO. A wait of 6-10 weeks after biopsy is not unusual before treatment begins. Cancer sometimes escapes before treatment, scans can sometimes detect but not always. If you get a second opinion they will need his urological medical records and probably biopsy slides so that might be something you may have to collect. Long term survival is good after treatment and new treatments are coming. Good luck.

Posts.Content: What Medicare or insurance actually allows / pays may be only a percentage of what they are billed. Have read that insurance often allows / pays 45- 50 thousand for radiation therapy, sometimes less . SBRT radiation done in only 5 sessions gets less than that. Seed radiation allowance is also less. Proton therapy is paid at a higher rate.

Posts.Title: The Friedman Book

Posts.Content: When I had an ultrasound, it did not show much besides the size of my prostate. I had the ultrasound done at the same time as the biopsy since they are both trans-rectal. A biopsy in the USA is an outpatient procedure where spring loaded needles shoot into the prostate to obtain tiny core samples. Mine stung a bit but did not really hurt much. I took antibiotics before the biopsy and had to take bowel prep regimine also. Your symptoms sound like proctitis to me. Infections can take a long time to resolve. Sometimes a different antibiotic is needed for an infection. Good luck.

Posts.Title: FDA approves Zytiga (abiraterone) for Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: As was mentioned, inflammation may raise PSA . The larger the prostate, the higher PSA tends to be. One gauge is PSA density that is PSA divided by prostate size. PSA density less than .12 is a good omen. In the USA , a biopsy is typically used to diagnose via needle samples. A biopsy here includes ultrasound that measures the size of the prostate. I'm not aware of the protocol in the UK . Most prostate cancer is not lethal. Good luck on your tests and health.

Posts.Content: UPDATE 1-FDA approves J&J advanced prostate cancer drug * To be sold under brand name Zytiga * Prolonged survival by 4 months in pivotal trial - U.S. health regulators on Thursday approved a Johnson & Johnson (JNJ.N) drug for advanced prostate cancer considered one of the most important medicines that the company had been developing. The Food and Drug Administration gave the green light to the drug, to be sold under the brand name Zytiga, nearly two month earlier than expected. Zytiga, known chemically as abiraterone, extended the lives of patients with advanced prostate cancer by an average of four months in a pivotal clinical trial. "Zytiga prolonged the lives of men with late-stage prostate cancer who had received prior treatments and had few available therapeutic options," Dr. Richard Pazdur, director of the FDA's Office of Oncology, said in a statement. (Reporting by Bill Berkrot)

Posts.Content: If his PSA was 65 in 2010, he should have had the biopsy then. At least the PSA does not appear to have doubled since then. With the biopsy, there are spring-loaded needles that go through the rectum and take little samples of the prostate. It is usually outpatient procedure. They also would use an ultrasound to determine the size of the prostate which you should know. PSA can occasionally go up from inflammation, infection and enlargement. Early detection can often help so he should go ahead with the biopsy to determine what is happening. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Catheter problem?

Posts.Content: If his PSA was 65 in 2010, he should have had the biopsy then. At least the PSA does not appear to have doubled since then. With the biopsy, there are spring-loaded needles that go through the rectum and take little samples of the prostate. It is usually outpatient procedure. They also would use an ultrasound to determine the size of the prostate which you should know. PSA can occasionally go up from inflammation, infection and enlargement. Early detection can often help so he should go ahead with the biopsy to determine what is happening. Good luck.

Posts.Title: PSA of 80

Posts.Content: Sorry for the diagnosis. I'm thinking he should be considered a (4+3) Gleason 7 also. You might want to obtain a copy of his biopsy report , PSA and any scans completed just in case he receives treatment someplace out of town or in case a 2nd opinion is sought. A 2nd opinion would require his records. My 2nd opinion required the biopsy slides / core samples as well. MD Anderson is a huge cancer place in Texas and as mentioned might be considered. With bone mets he is likely to need hormone therapy / androgen deprivation therapy in the future. Good luck to both of you.

Posts.Title: Decisions

Posts.Content: Another idea is that Proscar or Avadart prevents the body from converting testosterone to DHT. A theory is that DHT / dihydrotestosterone fuels prostate cancer.
Posts.Title: Proscar for Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: Welcome. He has a serious condition. I am assuming he is on hormone therapy / adrogen deprivation . Some patients respond to that for a long time and some do not. Some patients get spot radiation for bone metastasis. A biopsy would reveal the Gleason number and I'm surprised he did not have a biopsy. Anyway, as was stated there are a lot of medicines coming for prostate and other cancers. What area do you live in? Good luck to both of you.

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear about the situation. I have read an account of a patient who responded to estrogen plus dexamethasone in a big way. That might be worth a shot. In regard to sequencing after recurrence, Provenge immunotherapy should be the first treatment which might retard the cancer process. This is what I have read. There are a lot of clinical trials and new treatments being developed. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: Pro Bono Cancer Clinics?

Posts.Content: A PSA of 1.7 has been considered typical for a male, depending on age. How old are you? PSA often trends higher as we age. Your PSA would not ordinarily warrant a biopsy yet. There is a blood test called FreePsa which you might get next time out. (high is better on this test.) Most prostate cancers are slow growing and that is why doctors are not very aggressive in testing for it. Good luck.

Posts.Title: New Memeber - First Post What to do, what to do????

Posts.Content: Welcome. In USA patients usually have a biopsy where they take needle samples of prostate tissue. A pathologist looks at the samples. The pathologist can issue a statement about the probable Gleason score (how aggressive the cells look.) As far as surgery, it can cause problems with urination control and ED (sex) sometimes. Often problems are temporary. What is his age? Good luck to you both.

Posts.Title: 1 year anniversary

Posts.Content: Welcome. Sorry your PSA seems to be trending up. You might want to retest in a month or so to confirm. Retesting might provide you with a PSA Doubling Time which can be of diagnostic assistance. If the PSA trend is confirmed, you might consider salvage radiation. It often works but not always. Hormone Therapy / androgen deprivation might be another treatment you could see. Hope the PSA was an error. Good luck with your health. P.S. how old are you?

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear about his condition. Zytiga works to prevent production of testosterone. It is new and expensive. May not work forever. Xgeva works on bone symptoms I think. Provenge is an expensive vaccine product the Medicare might pay for. Keto is a fungal med that some patients take and might help some . Enzalutamide / MDV3100 is pending approval and works on hormone receptors. Cabozantinib / XL184 is pending for thyroid cancer and helps with bone condition. Prostvac vaccine is in trials. There are a lot of medicines and therapies being tested and I hope one of them helps him. Good luck.

I'm thinking he does need treatment since he is young and has a long time for the cancer to grow and spread. The 14,13, 11 are the PSA results? Stopping or delaying the cancer in order to live longer is the main thing to focus on. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Surgery scheduled Scared to death - help

Posts.Content: Welcome. Are you from the USA? An enlarged prostate can raise PSA somewhat. Benign prostate tissue generates some PSA. And cancer can generate higher PSA. There is controversy about PSA tests. I think you should get one to have a base number. An extremely high PSA might be a marker for prostate cancer as well. There is another blood test called a Free PSA that can be informative (higher is better on the Free PSA test.) An enlarged prostate is not a sign of cancer and is often benign. Some people with enlarged prostates need TURP procedures to enlarge the channel to the bladder. Anyway good luck on your condition.

Posts.Title: Wait til next year?

Posts.Content: Welcome and sorry you had to come here. Sounds like a significant cancer. A lot of patients can get by with urinary pads after the catheter comes out rather than diapers. There are good books by Walsh or Scardino. Am not sure if surgery would control such a cancer. Hormone therapy and radiation are sometimes done in addition to or instead of surgery. A theory is that surgery will debulk the tumors. Sounds like you are making excellent progress preparing. Congratulate yourself for your efforts. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Wait til next year?

Posts.Content: Clinical trials have shown that vegetarian diets will retard the progression of prostate cancer, not cure it. Proscar , Avodart medicines and possibly saw palmetto will mask PSA numbers. Some of the supplements may slow the progression of prostate cancer. Most promising are IP6, turmeric / curcumin and the medicine metformin used off-label. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed, many questions

Posts.Content: Hello. I'm thinking your condition is not unusual at your age. You might consider a second opinion of the biopsy samples. Something important is your PSA density, which is PSA divided by prostate size. What size is your prostate? The density might suggest your prognosis. Size is also a complicating factor. Besides Active Surveillance, there is Focal Ablation of tiny tumors that is only done at a few centers in the USA. You have a lot of time to decide if treatment is needed at some point. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Totally Shocked, and not in a good way

Posts.Content: Inflammation, infection, sex and enlargement can be factors. If your PSA is 14 then you should be seeing a urologist in my opinion. Steady weight and lack of pain don't preclude cancer. Some patients try a course of an antibiotic before retesting PSA. There are other blood tests such as free PSA and PHI that might be used. The biopsy with spring-loaded needles is the main test. How is your urine flow? Enlargement with cause slow flow. Anyway, good luck.

Posts.Signature: DOB Sept. 1947. Prostate cancer Gleason 7 (3+4), PSA 5 in Oct 2010. Cryoablation Jan. 2011. Had some complications. Experienced nocturia, irritable bladder summer 2011. "Agent Orange"compensation from VA Oct 2011. PSA: .05 01/26/2012, .06 6/26/2012, .04 12/24/2012, .04 6/26/13, .05 1/27/14, .05 10/21/14, .04 10/15 I am eating vegan mostly plus a little fish. Take some supplements. (Any advice given is the personal opinion of a layman and is not intended to replace the advice of a health professional.)
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed, many questions

Posts.Content: Hi. The DRE can raise PSA somewhat, better to draw blood before DRE. Many cases of prostate cancer are slow growing. We might be able to say more after you receive pathology report from biopsy. Hang in there.

Posts.Title: High PSA reading

Posts.Content: I received 100% for a year and now get 20% for residual symptoms. I had other insurance and used that for treatment. But its good to know the VA has to treat me if I want. There was a recent trial called Chaarted that showed the survival benefit of Hormone Therapy added to chemo in patients who were still hormone sensitive. Your father could try docetaxel and drop it if it was too unpleasant. Docetaxel chemo is not supposed to be bad for side effects. There are also clinical trials. Living 15+ years with high risk prostate cancer is an achievement. I hope you find a treatment that helps. These are some clinical trials he might qualify for: https://sites.google.com/site/prostatecancerpipeline/ P.S. Chuck, thanks for the kind words
Posts.Title: Iowa Veteran looking at Chemo as next option for Prostate Cancer Treatment

Posts.Content: Hello. I'm thinking your condition is not unusual at your age. You might consider a second opinion of the biopsy samples. Something important is your PSA density, which is PSA divided by prostate size. What size is your prostate? The density might suggest your prognosis. Size is also a complicating factor. Besides Active Surveillance, there is Focal Ablation of tiny tumors that is only done at a few centers in the USA. You have a lot of time to decide if treatment is needed at some point. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed, many questions

Posts.Content: PSA rise could be from infection or inflammation. Some people get a course of antibiotic and then have PSA retested. You could also get a Free PSA blood test (higher percent is better.) I would try these two things first. If they don't eliminate anything then a biopsy might be your next option. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Hi

Posts.Content: Hello. Factors to consider are age, PSA history and doubling time, PSA density (PSA divided by prostate size). There are tests such as free PSA . There are some new tests approved such as 4kscore test which may not yet be covered by insurance. If you can provide more details, we might offer an opinion. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed, many questions

Posts.Content: Welcome. There may be a problem with the dates. Year 2012 dates may be indicated as 2011, not sure. The end is not near. You may have a fairlly short PSA doubling time which is not too good. Hormone therapy may help to control the cancer, sometimes for years. There are a lot of new medicines, approved and in the pipeline which can slow the cancer. Doctors vary on the use of early hormone therapy. I personally think it is good to start soon but thats just my opinion. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed, many questions

Posts.Content: Welcome I have no experience with this subset of prostate cancer. There is a trial of a medicine that might be interesting: MLN8237 oral med for neuroendocrine or mcrpc prostate cancer Phase II began Feb. 2013 http://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/N...8?term=MLN8237 Good luck.
Posts.Title: Treatment neuroendocrine differentiation

Posts.Content: Yes, radiation has improved a lot. If you get it, try for most modern equipment from a major center. Some use 40 sessions. Some can do radiation in 5 strong sessions. You still have quite low PSA. Some act with PSA at .10 . Sometimes the cancer has spread beyond prostate bed, so radiation doesn't always work. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: High PSA reading

Posts.Content: Hello. I waited 3 weeks for second opinion. In total it was 2 months between biopsy and treatment for me. I was in a hurry to get a treatment. My urologists both told me radiation was as good an option as surgery. Sometimes VA might send a patient out for treatment if special treatment is needed. I chose not to go through VA partly because I read of radiation errors at one VA hospital and partly because I was in a hurry. What is your age and prostate size? Good luck with your decision.

Posts.Title: High PSA reading

Posts.Content: Sometimes PSA can jump from inflammation or enlargement or infection. Since prostate cancer usually grows slowly, there may be no rush for another biopsy. A multiparametric MRI is available at some large centers. There is a free PSA blood test that sometimes provides some info. If you know the prostate size, you can compute PSA density. There are other blood tests. Good luck with your research and efforts.

Posts.Title: Questioning next steps after Dad's negative biopsy

Posts.Content: Hello. I waited 3 weeks for second opinion. In total it was 2 months between biopsy and treatment for me. I was in a hurry to get a treatment. My urologists both told me radiation was as good an option as surgery. Sometimes VA might send a patient out for treatment if special treatment is needed. I chose not to go through VA partly because I read of radiation errors at one VA hospital and partly because I was in a hurry. What is your age and prostate size? Good luck with your decision.

Posts.Title: Recently diagnosed with prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Hi. it's hard to predict the future. Your PSA doubling time after surgery is one possible indicator to consider. You certainly have tried the treatments the doctors recommended and have made a real effort. I hope the radiation got it. There are also a lot of other treatments available and more are being developed. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Interpreation of my Gleason

Posts.Content: You can not prevent it or reverse it with diet or exercise. A study at UCSF suggested early stage prostate cancer patients might substantially slow the time it took for PSA to double through vegetable based diet. The only animal product they consumed was egg white.

Posts.Title: Questioning next steps after Dad's negative biopsy

Posts.Content: Welcome. Sounds like a fairly mild diagnosis for cancer. Options are Active Surveilance (which can change later), surgery or radiation.. There is a good short introductory book by dr sheldon marks. A longer book by dr peter scardino and a real long book by dr. patrick walsh. The cancer you describe might take 15 years or more to cause death, so there is no rush to make a decision or decide. It does vary though. Assuming there was no nodule felt on prostate, you might be stage T1C. You want to know the size of the prostate and might obtain a copy of biopsy report. Good luck to you. P.S. The PSA doubling time and PSA density can be informative to a decison.

Posts.Title: Holistic approach

Posts.Content: Hello. (There have been cases where bone metastasis is misdiagnosed at former injury areas.) So 2nd opinion about scans is in order. Radiation of the prostate bed and Hormone Therapy (androgen deprivation) are possible treatments. Hormone Therapy can sometimes work for years but it varies. For bone mets there is spot radiation. There are a lot of treatments being developed. Good luck to you both.

Posts.Title: Psa of 0.11 after prostate removal

Posts.Content: The few months is an average for those who have failed hormone therapy / androgen deprivation therapy. Some of had big results and some no benefit. Most of these new meds can't be used until hormone therapy fails. If taken earlier they might have bigger benefit in survival. Provenge vaccine is another approved treatment to mention. Michael Milken is surviving a long time with the aid of a personal chef to cook a strict diet regimen. Some studies have shown a benefit to a vegan diet. Some trials are looking at the benefit of the medicine metformin which I take. You can look at diet, supplements and clinical trials in addition to the new super expensive meds. Are you on hormone therapy now? What is your age? Anyway, good luck finding a treatment or trial.

Posts.Title: Challenge  name a successful prostrate drug

Posts.Content: Factors you should know include PSA , PSA doubling time and how many metastatic growths. I knew of a patient who took estrogen instead of typical hormone therapy. He did well for years. Hormone therapy combined with docetaxel might extend life for quite a while. Chemo for prostate cancer usually has milder side effects than old chemo drugs used to have. Good luck to you both.

Posts.Title: Dad diagnosed stage 4, refusing treatment

Posts.Content: In the past, a person would have to have a Gleason score of 6 or less, for Active Surveillance. The number of postive cores would have to be small. And the percent of cancer in each core would have to be fairly small. The criteria bend some for older patients according to some, with AS being more viable for older patients with somewhat more significant cancer than younger patients with the same stats. So age is another factor to consider.

Posts.Title: Considerations for Stepping up from Watchful Waiting

Posts.Content: Your questions are basically comprehensive. You should ask for a copy of the biopsy report produced by the pathologist. Don't think you need to ask about a false positive. If the biopsy report is negative then you might be good to go for 6-12 months. Don't think most places do an MRI after negative biopsy. Good luck with your appointment.

Posts.Title: Dad is 87. Some questions -- need some possibilities

Posts.Content: Welcome. Prostate cancer sometimes involves cells in the prostate bed, sometimes cells beyond the bed which are hard to detect , micromets can hide in system dormant for years. Prostate cancer often moves to bones eventually. Radiation can bring temporary bowel discomfort and urinary urgency. He would not have to avoid anyone. He should have a number of years to live. Some people respond to hormone therapy for many years but it varies. There are a lot of new treatments coming but they are expensive. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Considerations for Stepping up from Watchful Waiting

Posts.Content: In USA patients might get Casodex instead of Flutamide. The castration causes low testosterone and patients vary on that.Some respond for 6 months to low testosterone and some respond for years. Once the PSA starts rising after castration, then they are castration resistant and that is bad. I have read of cases where PSA rises with low testosterone and the patient responded to patches or pills containing estrogen plus a steroid dexamethasone. I hope your father's PSA is stable for a long time after the castration. Good luck.

Posts.Title: post-castration treatment and life expectancy

Posts.Content: Hi. Hormone Therapy might keep his cancer at bay for some time. It varies how long. Sometimes it works for many years. Sometimes they do salvage radiation on prostate bed. If HT fails, then he would qualify for newer medicines and clinical trials. So HT is usually a prerequisite for other treatments, if needed. Once PSA is high, the wholistic stuff might not help that much. I'm trying for vegan diet and take supplements, but my PSA is low so far. How old is he? Good luck to you both.

Posts.Title: The Forum

Posts.Content: Hello. The doctors would not do a radical prostatectomy for prevention due to side effects and a small risk of death from the operation. In USA with group insurance the total fees might be 30,000 dollars plus for insurance company and co-pay to patient. The insurance company would not pay without a diagnosis of cancer. There are smaller cheaper procedures such as TURP for enlargement. Some doctors don't do operation on patients older than 72 or so. Prostate cancer is rare before age 40.

AgeInfo.Phrase: cancer is rare before age 40 <Z> <Z> <Z> <Z> <Z>

Posts.Title: Prostatectomy

Posts.Content: The 4kScore test just came out. It uses 4 factors to project risk. An article said it costs $395 and is not yet covered by insurance. The Free PSA blood test is one of the 4 and can be taken separately. It should be covered by insurance. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Alternatives to Biopsy for Determining PC ?

Posts.Content: Cyberknife is a form of SBRT. Getting it in 5 sessions is called hypofractionation. It is usually effective. Could cause temp urinary or colon irritation. I lost quite a bit of weight on a high fiber diet, which I recommend. Good luck on your decision and health.

For example, most institutional oncologists would not prescribe metformin but Myers does.etc I think a patient only sees him once or twice a year and communicates via telephone or email. Posts.Title: Dr Snuffy Myers

Posts.Content: Welcome. PSA itself can go up from inflammation, infection, sex before blood draw. Your PSA is not super high. The FreePSA does not look real good. Prostate cancer usually takes a decade to develop and often grows slowly. Some try an antibiotic before blood draw to rule out infection. You might try to insist on another PSA within 2 months. Your are diligent to be concerned but it is not an emergency. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: PSA results question

Posts.Content: Welcome. What is your PSA now? What size is the prostate? What is the PSA doubling time? I tend to agree that Active Surveilance could be the way to go. At least for now. The kind of cancer diagnosed might take 20 or more years to get you. If ever. There is also Targeted Focal Therapy available at a few sites using laser or freezing. There is a clincial trial called NX-1207 which uses an injection for early cancer. Active Surveilance could be dropped later. Besides testing , AS can include diet and a few supplements. Early clinical trials suggest that a strict diet might retard the cancer even more. Also to consider is that there might be more effective treatments 5 years from now. There is no rush to decide what to do. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: Alternatives to Lupron

Posts.Content: Welcome. PSA of 2.7 is not high for that age. Gleason 7 is intermediate mutation of cells. Options are radiation or surgery for treatment. With treatment, most Gleason 7 patients live more than 10 years, often much more. The scans usually come back clean with that PSA. Urinary and sexual side effects of treatment vary. Surgery often has more severe side effects. Good luck with the decision and treatment.

Posts.Title: 4 months after Da Vinci, PSA at .84 -- Now looking at future

Posts.Content: Welcome. From what I have read, proton therapy is not especially more effective than some other forms of radiation, but is often more expensive. If you do choose radiation, it should be from a major center using state of the art equipment. There is no rush to make a decision. You could get a second opinion on pathology slides. Or if you consult with Johns Hopkins or Cleveland Clinic, they will want to see the slides anyway. A consult will require your medical records. Good luck.

Posts.Title: psa question

Posts.Content: Welcome. Getting free PSA might inform you, (higher is better.) With abnormal DRE your concern is reasonable. The PSA is not that unusual. BPH, inflammation and infection may raise. Most prostate cancers are slow growing, many are indolent. In the past most urologists were eager to perform biopsies. Now the wheel has turned and some are less aggressive . You seem to have a good plan. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Prostate Questions

Posts.Content: Hello. The biopsy will not spread the prostate cancer, if you have it. It uses spring loaded needles through the rectum and sometimes is slightly painful. It is outpatient. Yes, a free PSA test would be helpful. What was your PSA number? That is something you should know. Prostate cancer takes many years to develop and is often slow growing, but not always. I don't know the reason the doctors suspected prostate cancer so can't guess what the situation is. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Help with tips for coping with long term nephrostomy into both kidneys.

Posts.Content: Welcome. If the PSA is going up while on hormone therapy / androgen deprivation, that would be castration resistant prostate cancer. CRPC. He should be seeing an oncologist about treatment. Having low weight is a positive in fighting prostate cancer before late stages. There are a lot of new medicines approved and meds in the pipeline for prostate cancer. Many are expensive. There are also clinical trials. Good luck to you both. P.S. How old is he?

Posts.Title: Prostate Biopsy

Posts.Content: Sorry you have to be here. I would not focus on diet and alternative stuff right now. Your primary treatment is the most important thing. If I were in your shoes, I would opt for radiation. Hormone Therapy might make the radiation more potent. Radiation is likely to keep you alive for a decade at the minimum and probably much more. A lot of people are hoping for a perfect decision. Sometimes there is no perfect decision with drawbacks either way. I hope you can make a decision and not look back. Good luck.

Posts.Title: PSA 59, Gleason 7, Biopsy 92% cancer in all lobes of prostrate. Still contained

Posts.Content: Welcome. Prostate cancer is usually diagnosed with a biopsy unless the PSA is super high. The free PSA is not that bad. Cystoscopy might detection bladder problem causing bleeding. A prostate biopsy is the most typical diagnostic test. MRI's are used in some countries to diagnose. How old is your husband? As the others said, prostate cancer is often slow growing and treatable. The problem could be something else as well. Good luck.

Posts.Title: What's your preference?

Posts.Content: Hi, A bone scan would not find micromets, I'm thinking. Most of the time bone scans don't find much with low PSA . The size of your prostate can limit options. Do you know the size? Most doctors would not recommend active surveillance with 4+3 Gleason 7. Radiation or surgery might be the most likely options. Many prostate cancers grow slowly. Your experts in Scotland May have other ideas. Good luck.

Posts.Title: prostate riddles

Posts.Content: Welcome. Sorry you have to come here. The Gleason 6 is not that bad but the PSA is not good. Surgery and radiaton are the primary treatments. Surgery might be most curative but might have more side effects involving continence and ED. It varies on these. Radiation includes beam radiation over maybe 40 days. Or seed radiation in a 1 day procedure. Less common treatments are HIFU and cryo. Active surveilance is used by some but your PSA might not be appropriate. The decision is quite difficult. You should live a long time if treated. The 10 year cure rate is high. Good luck.

Posts.Title: New guy - 46 yo, diagnosed on 8/27

Posts.Content: Hi. He might qualify for Provenge, that will boost his immune system. it costs a lot and Medicare B might cover it. Spot radiation can sometimes treat bone spots. Hormone therapy plus docetaxel chemo has extended survival. Oncologists have a number of treatments including new meds like Zytiga, Xtandi, Xofigo There are also a lot of clinical trials. I hope he has a good oncologist. Good luck.
Posts.Title: First Post: Please help me understand about my Dad - metastatic?

Posts.Content: Welcome. It sounds like you are on top of things during a stressful time. Some people get Active Surveillance for Gleason 6. With Gleason 7, it is more controversial although you have a small amount on biopsy. There are a few places that do Targeted Focal Therapy using spot lasers or spot freezing. Seed radiation often has lower initial side effects. There is a trial of an injection NX-1207 which is for early prostate cancer. Phase II. As you realize, there is no rush to decide. Good luck with the decision and health.

Posts.Content: There are a lot of old injuries that are ambiguous on bone scans. Suggest you obtain a biopsy of "met" since PSA is low for a met. Then again, a met usually shrinks on Lupron. If he does not really have a met, he could be on the wrong protocol. PSA is not a great test. Good luck with testing and treatment.

Posts.Title: Another Excellent Book

Posts.Content: I think I read that Proton therapy and SBRT are about equally effective. Neither usually create many side effects if done at a major center. The Proton machines used to cost a mint to build and therapy was very expensive. Five sessions of hypofractionated SBRT is less expensive and about as effective. I don't know if your prostate size would preclude these therapies. A radiation oncologist would know. Good luck deciding.

Posts.Title: New guy - 46 yo, diagnosed on 8/27

Posts.Content: Inflammation contributes to the aggressiveness of some cancers. There are some medicines and supplements that lower C-reactive protein, a marker of inflammation in the body. Dr. Charles "Snuffy" Meyers, an oncologist, has his own anti-proliferation program of diet and supplements. Meyers has done well with some very advanced cases using traditional and integrative approaches together. So, I doubt the doctor in question is making any money on the site . There are many urologists that only know surgery and hormones. The doctor mentioned seems to have adopted a more integrative approach. If I remember, this site does not like the concept of alternative medicine. The doctor mentioned does not seem to be alternative, but integrative.

Posts.Title: Final Days

Posts.Content: Hello. Congrats on the sphincter. Androgen Deprivation Therapy / Hormone therapy is still the main treatment after recurrence. Sometimes works for months and sometimes for many years. Salvage radiation I believe you have declined. Keto and leukine are other options after ADT. Chemo (poisons) are sometimes tried after ADT has failed to work any longer. One vaccine approved (Provenge) for castration refractory PC. Two other expensive treatments approved for CRPC (maybe after chemo.) Some people are also using diet and supplements to augment treatment. UCSF has a prostate treatment guide. http://www.ucsfhealth.org/education/...nts/index.html http://www.hindawi.com/journals/pc/2012/327253/ Good luck.

Posts.Title: Doubling Rate 1 yr and Artificial Sphincter

Posts.Content: Apparently, you have just had a partial biopsy. After diagnosis, prostate cancer can continue for months to decades. If you have very high PSA then death might be closer. Advanced prostate cancer often goes to bone tissue where it causes pain. The pain is often controlled with spot radiation to the bone. Terminal patients take pain meds. Since you seem to have just been diagnosed, I wonder if you might live for years before the prostate cancer becomes advanced. Some patients who decline radiation or surgery, control the cancer for a long time with Hormone Therapy , androgen deprivation. How old are you and what was your PSA? Anyway, good luck to you.

Posts.Title: Final Days

Posts.Content: Sorry you had that experience. These complications happen about 1% of the time. Besides biopsy, there are blood tests like Free PSA and PHI. It might have been better to have those blood tests instead. Many cancer patients find out about their cancer with biopsy's. My own biopsy was unpleasant but discovered my prostate cancer. Because of later treatment, I will live longer. So I would try to keep biopsy's in perspective. Hopefully some day soon there will be a better way. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Never again!

Posts.Content: Welcome. As far as surgery, DaVinci robotic is becoming popular and may offer slightly faster recovery from surgery. If you choose surgery, a very experienced surgeon is recommended. Surgery allows examination of the tissue by a pathologist which is an advantage over radiation. The more modern radiation procedures have good rates of cure or control at 10 years out. Seed, IGRT, LINAC, SBRT, IMRT and proton are options. You are likely to live 10 years without treatment I was told with similar or worse stats. So there is no rush to receive treatment. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Looking for some reassurance!!

Posts.Content: Some urologists will not operate on men over the age of 70. The idea is that at a certain age, radiation is safer than surgery. The size of the prostate and any current urinary problems can be a factor in the decision. If you have urinary slowing now, surgery might be more desirable. A Gleason 6 is fairly typical for men your age. I would recommend AS, or radiation if you want treatment. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Gleason 6

Posts.Content: Hello. If you monitor your prostate health you are less likely to be diagnosed with any late-stage cancer. Diagnosis at an early stage has a good prognosis. Besides PSA there is a free PSA blood test. A newer test is the PHI test which is promising for detection. I would recommend reading the book "Anticancer". A vegan diet with a few supplements might delay or mitigate any cancer that might eventually develop. There was a clinical trial by Dr. Dean Ornish using a vegan diet plus some supplements. The program slowed the progress of the cancer. The diabetes med metformin is being studied for its effect of slowing or preventing some cancers including prostate cancer. Ten years from now they will very likely have much more effective treatments than they do now. Good luck.

I had complications from treatment and another doctor did not return my email directly to him at major hospital. What you are experiencing is very common. If you can obtain the biopsy report, that probably will be sufficient to research. Non-emergency communications are usually through office appointments. Some major centers have a system that takes weeks to obtain medical records from a 3rd party. (The higher the expectations, the more llikely we are to be disappointed.) Good luck.

Posts.Title: Uncommunicative Medical Professionals

Posts.Content: Welcome. I would recommend finding out exactly what your PSA is. PSA should be undetectable 3 months after surgery. Undetectable sometimes means less than .04 but the definition varies a little. You should be receiving a pretty sensitive PSA test. If the PSA is barely detectable but doesn't move than that might be OK for now. (I misread this and thought you were seeing a urologist.) Am thinking that tracking the PSA is often the main focus to gauge success of treatment. If PSA is significantly detectable then a treatment plan might be on the table.Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: How long does contact with surgeon last?

Posts.Content: PSA often trends up somewhat slowly over time. A quick dramatic rise is unusual and could be infection or inflammation.Antibiotic was a good suggestion. In the USA they usually do a biopsy before an MRI.I don't know that a standard MRI would show everything you want to know. Anyway, good luck.

Posts.Title: Surprise

Posts.Content: Welcome. What country are you from? I would ask for the Gleason score. You might want a copy of the pathology report. With castration, he will not need hormone therapy. Hopefully, his PSA would go down after castration. If his PSA is going up after castration, then he would have castration resistant prostate cancer. Which means the cancer cells would grow independent of male hormones. You should ask what kind of chemotherapy they have in mind. I hope the castration works for a long time. Good luck.

Posts.Title: New and Unsure

Posts.Content: I would say you don't yet meet the standard of recurrence after radiation treatments. Suggest you continue to get PSA tests to monitor the situation. There are a lot of articles about things that have promise to retard prostate cancer progression such as vegetarian diet, IP6, niacinamide, d-limonene, turmeric, baby aspirin and prescription metformin. Would look at some of the integrative things since it would be too soon for hormone therapy. Good luck.

Posts.Title: What to Do about Conflicting Advice

Posts.Content: Hi. The wait seems unreasonable to me. Maybe you could call around and get an appointment with another urologist office. I think I had a 10 day wait for my biopsy and then had to wait 13 days to find out that I had prostate cancer because they did not call me. Anyway, it might be worth calling around. They often make patients wait for a while after a biopsy to perform surgery if that is what is chosen. Good luck.

Posts.Title: PSA .7 DRE showed Mass

Posts.Content: Welcome Tim. Sorry for the diagnosis. With a PSA over 100, surgery would not cure and can cause a lot of side effects. I'm guessing that hormone therapy (androgen deprivation therapy) might be a main treatment. Radiation concurrent with the hormone therapy might be added. Patients often live for quite a few years with these treatments. Good luck finding the best treatment.

Posts.Title: Psa 300+

Posts.Content: Welcome. I think the radiation and hormone therapy are to try to nip any spread in the bud, so to speak. They are probably just suspecting spread to justify these additional treatments. The PSA result is a definite plus for him. If there were spread, the radiation would probably kill or control it for many, many years. They can not be sure about metastasis, some of which can be microscopic and take many years to reappear. He will probably live a long time in any case. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Digital Rectal Exam Question

Posts.Content: Welcome. I'm thinking that the PSA threshold is higher after radiation therapy than surgery. (Nadir +2 might be a standard for some.) If the standard is nadir +2, then you would have a way to go. Others might have a different viewpoint. I am no expert. If you did need treatment, it would probably be hormone therapy / androgen deprivation. A lot of people are on diet restrictions. Anyway, good luck with your consultation and possible treatment.

Posts.Title: Will find out blood results tomorrow

Posts.Content: Hello. Some of the Targeted Focal Therapy involves lasers. Just at a few places in USA. There are also some new injections that look interesting. NX-1207 is in Phase II for prostate cancer involving an injection into prostate tissue. ProstAtak is another injection in trials but might include some radiation. I would suggest Targeted Focal Therapy now or an experimental injection followed by diet changes. If you choose Active Surveilance, you could do a biopsy every 18 months or so. Am thinking you could avoid extensive treatment for 5-10 years with your stats. Good luck.

Posts.Title: diagnosed with prostate cancer at age 41

Posts.Content: Hello. Some of the Targeted Focal Therapy involves lasers. Just at a few places in USA. There are also some new injections that look interesting. NX-1207 is in Phase II for prostate cancer involving an injection into prostate tissue. ProstAtak is another injection in trials but might include some radiation. I would suggest Targeted Focal Therapy now or an experimental injection followed by diet changes. If you choose Active Surveilance, you could do a biopsy every 18 months or so. Am thinking you could avoid extensive treatment for 5-10 years with your stats. Good luck.

Posts.Title: PSA Bumping up 5 years after SRT

Posts.Content: First I will tell you that I have had nurses and even doctors mispronounce test results. I had a PSA of 0.05 and the Nurse Practitioner said over the phone that I had 0.5 which would be bad. Only on reading the result was I able to see what it was, to my relief. You want to read or at least confirm the number. If the PSA is actually 0.3, then you would be looking at Salvage Radiation in the near future. They radiate the prostate bed. I hope it was a mistake. Good luck.

Some might suggest radiation treatments. Some patients recieve injections to lower testosterone that might fuel the cancer. This is also know as Androgen Deprivation or Hormone Therapy. Many patients live for a long time with your kind of stats. And there are new treatments in the pipeline. Anyway good luck on your care.

Posts.Title: New battle to commence

Posts.Content: Welcome. They did much less testing on me. The iliac finding might be just an anomoly as there are many false suspicians from imaging. With your stats bone spread would be unlikely, I'm guessing. Surgery might produce ED and urinary incontinence such as have to wear pads on a temp or permanent basis. These vary. There is usually 7 or 8 days with a catheter inserted after surgery. Radiation as an option would involve 40 sessions or so of beam radiation or 1 session inserting radioative seeds. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: How often Green Light surgery can be performed?

Posts.Content: Welcome. It sounds like the diagnosis came a little late in the disease or the man has a very aggressive case. In this case the first thing the doctors might try is hormone therapy / androgen deprivation to reduce testosterone. That sometimes works for some time. It varies. There are some new and expensive medicines to reduce testosterone production and block receptors. Spot radiation might be another option. There are several 2nd line treatments that work for some men for a while. Chemotherapy using cell poisons is a later option. There are a lot of new medicines and clinical trials coming along. Good luck.
Posts.Title: I need some help

Posts.Content: I think the Phoenix standard for recurrence after radiation is nadir plus 2. As was mentioned it takes a while for radiation to work and sometimes there is even a temp bounce. The urologist is not an expert on recurrence after radiation, the radiation oncologist is. Suggest you keep testing to find the nadir over the next year or so. Good luck.

Posts.Title: New battle to commence

Posts.Content: There are a lot of indolent prostate cancers that take 30 years to hurt a person. So a man of your age might not want to risk urinary problems for such a cancer. (the majority of old men die with a little chronic prostate cancer in their body.) That is one rationale for AS. Some men want to delay treatment as long as they can. But it is hard to predict which prostate cancers will be indolent. Free PSA , PSA density , nomograms or possibly some sophisticated other tests might provide clues.

Posts.Title: New battle to commence

Posts.Content: Welcome. First bear in mind that you have normal PSA. There is such a thing as prostate calcification but I'm not a doctor. I think I had a prostate stone on a CT scan. DRE feels for nodules on the prostate but are only one diagnostic tool of many. Large centers have MRI guided biopsy 's , smaller places just do biopsies usually on an outpatient basis. Prostate cancers are often slow growing. My urologist told me my prostate cancer would take 10 years to kill me if I did not get treatment. So there is no short term danger whatever your diagnosis. Scans some times pick up anomolies that later turn out to be insignificant. Good luck with urologist.

Posts.Title: Very concerned about dad's high PSA levels

Posts.Content: PSA of 63 could be an infection. It could also be cancer. There are several other blood tests that might be used such as free PSA. Some doctors try antibiotics to see if that affects PSA. There is a new PHI test. A biopsy might be in order later: It uses a machine that sends needles through the rectum into the prostate to obtain tissue samples. It stings some but is not traumatic. Do you remember your previous PSA? Good luck.

Posts.Title: 40 yo son of prostate cancer victim

Posts.Content: Are you in the United States? Bone scans and CT scans only show large metastasis, they miss micro metastasis. With these technologies, you may not learn enough. As was mentioned, some state of the art MRI technologies often provide more information. If the person does have aggressive cancer outside the prostate, radiation can be more potent treatment. Good luck.

They might also have pain. Some don't do scans until PSA is high. Hormone therapy to lower testosterone is one option. Some places use castration for that, some injections. In USA there are options of Provenge, Zytiga, Xtandi, etc. which are expensive. Buena suerte

Posts.Content: Yes, the biopsy should show the size of your Prostate. PSA density is PSA divided by Prostate size. You do want to know this.Unless you have a small Prostate, you are apt to be low risk. There is no rush to do anything with those stats. So you have plenty of time to educate yourself. Some patients get 2nd opinion on biopsy slides. There are some newer tests that purport to estimate risk. e.g. Prolaris. Good luck.

You are more than 5 years out and the cancer may have spread via micro metastases over these 5 years or even before the surgery. Salvage radiation only works some of the time if the cancer is still limited to the area of the prostate bed. Good luck with the decisions and future treatment.

Posts.Title: Ouch!

Posts.Content: Welcome. Gleason 7 comes in two varieties, (3+4) and (4+3). The 2nd one is more aggressive. But Gleason 7 is not always terrible. Sometimes is sort of medium grade. Many of us would like to know the patient's age, PSA number and history, and the number of cores found with cancer. More details can help. Proton therapy may not be better than other radiation treatments. It sometimes is more expensive. He should have good health insurance if this is the treatment of choice. My Gleason number was 7 (3+4) and the doctor told me I might live 10 years without treatment so it is not always super aggressive. It does vary. With treatment he is likely to live for quite a while. Good luck to you both.

Posts.Content: The PSA 2 years after surgery suggest recurrence. The decision now is whether to do Salvage Radiation. You might get the PSA drawn again to confirm the PSA. CT scans are routine but often do not show much, especially small mets. Hormone Therapy / androgen deprivation is another option to consider. Posts.Title: Salvage Radiation Experiences?

Posts.Content: Hi. Radiation might leave some benign prostate cells after treatment. Such cells can produce some PSA. The criteria for recurrence is Nadir +2 , the lowest post radiation PSA plus 2. So you are not at recurrence. It might be difficult to find the exact nadir if post radiation tests were not sensitive. Sounds like your doctor is on it. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Happy New Year. I hope 2015 brings new treatments, trials and discoveries.

The Gleason score has a primary and secondary number. The numbers reflect how much the cancer cells have mutated from regular cellsThe numbers go from 1 to 5 with 5 the most mutated and aggressive. The add the primary and secondary numbers together to get the total Gleason score.
Posts.Title: Dad Newly Diagnosed--Proton Therapy?

Posts.Content: Welcome. I see you are from Canada which might have different protocols than USA. What is your age? What is your prostate size? Any nodule felt on exam? Do you have a prior PSA result? Your cancer might take 15+ years to get you, so there is no rush to decide. Active Surveilance would be reasonable except for the PSA number. Other treatments are surgery, radiation, cryo / freezing, targeted focal therapy in just a few locations in USA, HIFU. There are a couple of injections for prostate cancer in trials. I wonder if the PSA number might reflect a large prostate. Anyway, good luck deciding on an approach.

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer Treatments

Posts.Content: Hello. The good news is they removed the bulk of the prostate cancer so it is debulked. I assume they removed the seminal vessicles. I think you wrote that the lymph nodes were clear. That is a definite plus. It is hard to say what the outcome will be after radiation. The radiation itself might cause temporary proctitis. If the cancer has not spread very far, the radiation might cure. If the cancer is systemic, then the cancer will continue to exist. Microscopic metastasis can occur and be undetectable so it is difficult to predict a permanent cure. After radiation, your husband is likely to live for years in the worst case. The best case scenario is that he would live for quite a long time. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Dad Newly Diagnosed--Proton Therapy?

Posts.Content: Bone scans and CT scans often pick up anomalies that are ambiguous and often are benign. The scans will not find micrometastases so it is possible there could be tiny metastasis that won't show on scans. With a PSA of 56, someone is going to have to make a determination on the likelihood of spread outside the prostate bed. Sometimes there is no certainty with prostate cancer. Nomograms , some of which are on the internet, compute some odds using PSA, Gleason score, etc. Factors to consider are the patient's age, the size of the prostate, whether there are any urinary problems now.Some institutions use PET scans or MRI to help with the decision. Good luck.

Posts.Title: New Member from Pensacola

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear the news. I'm thinking for Gleason 6 the options are prostatectomy and radiation. Less common treatments are Cryo (freezing), HIFU and Active Surveilance. Surgery sometimes creates temp or perm urinary side effects as well as ED. Sometimes these can be severe but often improve with recovery. There is no emergency to decide right now on the treatment. Without treatment he will likely live for more than a decade. At age 40 he does have a long time for any cancer to grow without treatment. You have time to get a 2nd opinion which might include a radiation oncologist. 2nd opinions often require the collection of medical records possibly including pathology slides. Making a decision is difficult. Good luck. P.S. He should not need another biopsy since the biopsy slides contain tissue samples that can be examined.

Posts.Title: What clinics/MDs around Boston have the most advanced technology?...

Posts.Content: Welcome. I see you are from Canada which might have different protocols than USA. What is your age? What is your prostate size? Any nodule felt on exam? Do you have a prior PSA result? Your cancer might take 15+ years to get you, so there is no rush to decide. Active Surveilance would be reasonable except for the PSA number. Other treatments are surgery, radiation, cryo / freezing, targeted focal therapy in just a few locations in USA, HIFU. There are a couple of injections for prostate cancer in trials. I wonder if the PSA number might reflect a large prostate. Anyway, good luck deciding on an approach.

Posts.Title: 61 yo husband newly diagnosed with high risk prostrate cancer

Posts.Content: If a biopsy finds prostate cancer and you'r are a Viet Nam vet, the VA has to assume there is a service connection and give you compensation. Mine took about 9 months after the application was submitted. I got retroactive money for the delay. I got 100 per cent for over a year and a half and then I get 20 per cent from now on. If you did have prostate cancer, you would very likely live for a long time with treatment.

Posts.Title: New Member from Pensacola

Posts.Content: Hi. As Chuck said, Active Surveillance is an option that might delay surgery for many years. Another option is Targeted Focal Therapy or Ablation were they only target the small tumor. It is only done at a few places in the USA. You could study the situation for a long time. A couple of important factors we should know are Prostate size and PSA history. Could you provide them? Surgery might make your urination better but 1-2% of the time patients lose some urinary control. Take your time before making a decision. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Biopsy is positive for cancer ... now what?

Posts.Content: The PSA with cancer does not usually rise that dramatically from such a low number. Prostate inflammation or infection would be more likely. A course of antibiotic might be good to try to see it it helps. I would try the antibiotic and then have the PSA re-tested. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Fast PSA rises

Posts.Content: Welcome. It appears to me that the PSA is steadily going up. A primary doctor could order a free PSA . You could get that first or go directly to a urologist, who should be an expert on prostate health. In any case you should see a urologist soon to diagnose whether it is inflammation, enlargement or cancer. The majority of prostate cancers are not fatal. Good luck.

Posts.Title: thanks for new treatments

Posts.Content: Welcome. The lab report from a pathologist listed the prostate size as 8 grams, 32.5 cc's. I don't know if that is the actual weight of prostate or the weight of the tissue removed during the TURP. A lot of patients find the prostate size through ultrasound done at the time of a biopsy. Would ask for clarification on that. The only negative I see is that PSA went up between Dec. 2011 and summer of 2012. PSA velocity is a factor in decision. You have no need to rush to any decison since you might live 20 years or more with this cancer. And they will be coming up with more effective treatments in the future. Active Surveilance involves periodic testing of PSA and biopsy's. It usually involves very healthy diet and some supplements. Some take metformin by prescription. Active Surveilance can be ended at any time there is a change. Good luck with your condition.

Posts.Content: I heard Cancer Treatment Centers of America has a lot of music/art therapy, massage, etc., all of which insurance does not pay- you do. I don't know about their other unusual therapies. Also don't know much about what is available in Germany. 177Lu-J591 radio-immunotherapy is in trials in USA and looks to be improvement over Xofigo. There is a new related injected radiotherapy available in Heidelburg called Actinium-225-anti-PSMA .
Posts.Title: integrative therapies/alternative CTOA

Posts.Content: I guess you are from the UK. It would have been better if they had done the biopsy and treatment quickly. However, it might not have made much difference. Your partner has probably had some prostate cancer growing for 30 years in his body. Am not sure if the operation had a chance to cure him. If he had the biopsy years ago it might have made a difference. Hormone therapy / androgen deprivation can sometimes seem to control the cancer for a while. Radiation therapy sometimes can cure if done early. So I'm guessing he is looking at hormone therapy and or salvage radiation. What was his PSA that brought him to a biopsy? What is his age? Anyway, I hope he responds to treatment and lives a long time. Good luck.

Posts.Title: confused

Posts.Content: Kenny, To get into a trial one must find a trial that will include but not exclude the patient. A really good medical oncologist might be able to expedite the search. Each trial lists the exclusion criteria and the trial's contact person/ telephone number at each location. A lot of research is often needed to find a qualifying trial. And some trials only offer the new treatment to half the patients, the other half might get a routine treatment plus a placebo at first.
Posts.Title: Prostate cancer 4 1/2 years stage 4 . psa rose highest level 39 from 6 after chemo.

Posts.Content: Active Surveillance sounds reasonable IMO. Surgery has a significant risk for sexual complications and a smaller risk for urinary problems. I would not be that concerned about the possibility of Proscar or Avadart affecting sex since sex ability declines anyway with age. There are variations of TURP that can improve urination, but these can have side effects. There are always pro's and con's with every pca treatment option. Good luck.

Posts.Title: I see the newest US News Hospital Rankings are out.....

Posts.Content: Hello, You should know PSA density, PSA divided by prostate size. A density under .12 is unlikely to kill a patient. Also number of positive scores and percent of cores in biopsy. Newer tests are mpMRI, 4k score, MI prostate score, etc. that have come out since Walsh book. AS has become more popular since the Walsh book, which was written by a man who does surgery. Most 67 year old men have prostate cancer in their body. Many of these cancers do not harm the individuals.Gleason 6 is unlikely to spread. If he has a small prostate and considerable cancer you might consider radiation.There is also focal ablation as a possibility. The more info we know, the better we can offer an opinion. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Questions to ask at upcoming Dr appt

Posts.Content: Hello. Its a very personal decision. AS might be OK in your circumstance with the possible exception of the PSA. If you have a large prostate the PSA might be reasonable. How big is your prostate? If you have a small prostate with that PSA then the cancer might be more significant. AS can include monitoring, diet, meds like metformin and supplements. Some here have made the choice of seed radiation (brachytherapy) and had good results with minimal side effects. Good luck with your decisons. http://www.medpagetoday.com/Hematolo...teCancer/34973
