Posts.Title: Active Surveillance vs. begin treatment?

Posts.Content: Hormone therapy is often helpful whether he has a prostate or not, after metastasis. A med a forgot is Xgeva. Historically, a lot of the old chemo poison type meds were not robust for pca. The newer chemo med Docetaxel / taxotere has helped many. If his PSA is down from hormone therapy, then the cancer is still considered androgen dependent. If the PSA goes up on HT / ADT, then he probably is castration refractory which is worse.

Posts.Title: Did husband's doctor make a big mistake?

Posts.Content: Sorry about your condition. How long you live might depend on where you are treated or what clinical trials you enter or what meds you are prescribed off-label. You are probably not too far from City of Hope center, for example. Alpharadin is pending with the FDA. Its sends radiation to bone mets. Cabozantinib (Marketed under the tradename Cometriq, formerly known as XL184) was approved for thyroid cancer. If you could get it off-label, it might help you. https://docs.google.com/document/d/1...Zhw/edit?pli=1 The link above is a list of clinical trials that might possibly help, if you were eligible. Many might be hard to get into though. Many trials may not be near you. You are in my prayers. Good luck to you.

One type of radiation is SBRT and it sometimes can be given in 5 sessions I think. Brachytherapy radiation has 2 types, permanent seeds or High Dose Rate temporary implants. These also might not require a big time commitment. But as was mentioned, you want the most effective treatment first. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Am I dying?

Posts.Content: Hello, You should know PSA density, PSA divided by prostate size. A density under .12 is unlikely to kill a patient. Also number of positive scores and percent of cores in biopsy. Newer tests are mpMRI, 4k score, MI prostate score, etc. that have come out since Walsh book. AS has become more popular since the Walsh book, which was written by a man who does surgery. Most 67 year old men have prostate cancer in their body. Many of these cancers do not harm the individuals.Gleason 6 is unlikely to spread. If he has a small prostate and considerable cancer you might consider radiation.There is also focal ablation as a possibility. The more info we know, the better we can offer an opinion. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Concerned Prostate Wife

Posts.Content: It sounds like the cancer might have spread outside the prostate prior to the surgery. It is not what we hope for. Patients and doctors hope for PSA around zero a few months after surgery. Prostate cells and prostate cancer cells generate PSA. Such radiation is sometimes called Salvage Radiation of the prostate area bed. It might help if you could provide more details such as Gleason number and your husbands age. Prostate cancer often grows slowly but varies. Good luck to you both.

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer options

Posts.Content: PSA of 63 could be an infection. It could also be cancer. There are several other blood tests that might be used such as free PSA. Some doctors try antibiotics to see if that affects PSA. There is a new PHI test. A biopsy might be in order later: It uses a machine that sends needles through the rectum into the prostate to obtain tissue samples. It stings some but is not traumatic. Do you remember your previous PSA? Good luck.

Seed radiation, External Beam radiation, surgery all seem reasonable. You did not mention Gleason Score, assume it was a Gleason 6 if Active Surveillance was on the table. You are likely to live for a long time, especially with treatment. There are also new treatments being developed for the future. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: Just Dx w/ gleason 4+3=7.

Posts.Content: Welcome. Gleason 7 comes in two varieties, (3+4) and (4+3). The 2nd one is more aggressive. But Gleason 7 is not always terrible. Sometimes is sort of medium grade. Many of us would like to know the patient's age, PSA number and history, and the number of cores found with cancer. More details can help. Proton therapy may not be better than other radiation treatments. It sometimes is more expensive. He should have good health insurance if this is the treatment of choice. My Gleason number was 7 (3+4) and the doctor told me I might live 10 years without treatment so it is not always super aggressive. It does vary. With treatment he is likely to live for quite a while. Good luck to you both.

Posts.Title: Dad Newly Diagnosed--Proton Therapy?

Posts.Content: Kenny, To get into a trial one must find a trial that will include but not exclude the patient. A really good medical oncologist might be able to expedite the search. Each trial lists the exclusion criteria and the trial's contact person/ telephone number at each location. A lot of research is often needed to find a qualifying trial. And some trials only offer the new treatment to half the patients, the other half might get a routine treatment plus a placebo at first.
Posts.Title: Prostate cancer 4 1/2 years stage 4 . psa rose highest level 39 from 6 after chemo.

Posts.Content: Are you in the United States? Bone scans and CT scans only show large metastasis, they miss micro metastasis. With these technologies, you may not learn enough. As was mentioned, some state of the art MRI technologies often provide more information. If the person does have aggressive cancer outside the prostate, radiation can be more potent treatment. Good luck.

There are links on the internet that compute PSA doubling time. You enter psa and date into the site and it computes doubling time. It has been a long time since treatment and radiation often does not work. Maybe others will have an opinion about radiation after 5 years or so. You might consult with an oncologist. What are his age, original PSA before diagnosis, pathology stats, etc? He still should have quite a few years to live at the worst case. Good luck.

Posts.Title: post radical prostectomy (2yrs4mo) PSA level 1.89 & concerned!

Posts.Content: I thought I read that Proscar will shrink the PSA in half or so. The PSA reading you get will not be a real PSA reading due to the drug effect. If the PSA does not drop in half or so, that is a bad sign. There are other blood tests including free PSA and PHI a new test. Don't know if Proscar would affect these other blood tests. It might have been better to get the PHI blood test before trying Proscar. I would recommend getting the PSA test fairly soon if you have been on Proscar over a month. By the way, what size was your prostate? Good luck.

You might be young for that. I would analyze the PSA and Free PSA percent to figure your next step. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Forum unstable - Too many sticky's?

Posts.Content: Welcome. I see you are from Canada which might have different protocols than USA. What is your age? What is your prostate size? Any nodule felt on exam? Do you have a prior PSA result? Your cancer might take 15+ years to get you, so there is no rush to decide. Active Surveilance would be reasonable except for the PSA number. Other treatments are surgery, radiation, cryo / freezing, targeted focal therapy in just a few locations in USA, HIFU. There are a couple of injections for prostate cancer in trials. I wonder if the PSA number might reflect a large prostate. Anyway, good luck deciding on an approach.

Posts.Title: help! newbie

An antibiotic may lower PSA or PSA could drop over time if it is from inflammation. It would take some time. Some MRI imaging that might be available at major centers might define what is there more precisely. I would look into MRI imaging at a major center. Posts.Title: Antibiotics and Second Opinion before Surgery

Posts.Content: Hi. One factor to consider is PSA density, PSA divided by prostate size. ( A large prostate is expected to generate more PSA .) What size is your prostate? I'm thinking bone pain would typically occur with a very high PSA. So monitoring PSA would gage that risk. I think you are prudent not to rush into anything. Posts.Content: Hi. One factor to consider is PSA density, PSA divided by prostate size. ( A large prostate is expected to generate more PSA .) What size is your prostate? I'm thinking bone pain would typically occur with a very high PSA. So monitoring PSA would gage that risk. I think you are prudent not to rush into anything. Some patients get multi-parametric MRI tests in conjunction with a later biopsy. There may be genetic testing of blood or biopsy slides. Good luck. You are more than 5 years out and the cancer may have spread via micro metastases over these 5 years or even before the surgery. Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with Prostate Cancer.

Posts.Content: Bone scans and CT scans often pick up anomalies that are ambiguous and often are benign. The scans will not find micrometastases so it is possible there could be tiny metastasis that won't show on scans. With a PSA of 56, someone is going to have to make a determination on the likelihood of spread outside the prostate bed. Sometimes there is no certainty with prostate cancer. Nomograms , some of which are on the internet, compute some odds using PSA, Gleason score, etc. Factors to consider are the patient's age, the size of the prostate, whether there are any urinary problems now.Some institutions use PET scans or MRI to help with the decision. Good luck.

Posts.Title: post radical prostectomy (2yrs4mo) PSA level 1.89 & concerned!

Posts.Content: Welcome. I see you are from Canada which might have different protocols than USA. What is your age? What is your prostate size? Any nodule felt on exam? Do you have a prior PSA result? Your cancer might take 15+ years to get you, so there is no rush to decide. Active Surveilance would be reasonable except for the PSA number. Other treatments are surgery, radiation, cryo / freezing, targeted focal therapy in just a few locations in USA, HIFU. There are a couple of injections for prostate cancer in trials. I wonder if the PSA number might reflect a large prostate. Anyway, good luck deciding on an approach.

Posts.Content: Welcome. It is unusual to diagnose seminal vesicle invasion on a biopsy. Surgery would debulk the tumor. Sounds like they are going after it aggressively. Some might argue that surgery would not be curative and that the radiation alone might be indicated. The stats go down some with seminal vesicle diagnosis. A lot of patients live for quite a number of years after primary treatment with such a biopsy. It does vary. Lymph node involvement would be a negative. After primary treatment, hormone therapy might be needed if there is recurrence. There are also a lot of new meds in the pipeline coming in future years. What size was the prostate? Good luck to you both.

Posts.Title: Expain aggressive cancer

Posts.Content: If the biopsy was for elevated PSA with no nodule felt on Digital Rectal Exam, then the stage would be T1C I'm thinking. Sounds like you have a fairly mild case from the biopsy stats mentioned except for the PSA. You might want to know the PSA density (PSA divided by prostate size.) Also the PSA doubling time before biopsy if you have that data. There is no real rush since you might live 15+ years without treatment. You could ask for 2nd opinion on biopsy slides. Your thinking sounds reasonable. Some might argue for Active Surveillance which takes a different pychology. Good luck with the decision and treatment.

Posts.Title: So im ready for the surgery

Posts.Content: Diet and supplements are controversial here and are not a cure. A study at Univ. of California San Francisco showed vegetarian with egg white slowed PSA doubling time for men on Active Surveilance. A lot of patients take Pom or extract thereof. Green Tea, broccoli, turmeric, tomato are also popular. Dr. Charles Snuffy Meyers has videos on Wordpress that encourage Mediterranean diet. It is possible the surgery left a bit of benign tissue. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: PSA rising after prostatectomy

Posts.Content: The hormone therapy / androgen deprivation therapy might keep him alive for many years. It sounds like he has responded to this so far. There was one trial of using vegetarian diet plus pomegranate and relaxation by dr. Dean Ornish. It slowed the PSA rise somewhat but was certainly no cure. Metformin diabetes drug (cheap) is being tested as adjunctive therapy. As was mentioned Zytiga looks helpful (works on hormones).expensive. Provenge vaccine is available / expensive and has some survival benefit. enzalutamide (MDV3100) works on androgen receptors and should be approved this year. Cabozantinib (XL-184) is in trials and has helped with bone mets for many. Alpharadin is in trials and looks promsing for bone situations. Prostvac is in trials. Some patients have responded to Ketoconazole. I'm thinking the best treatments now would be hormone therapy / ADT and the treatments mentioned. There are many others in trials. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Any success stories with alternative treatments? Please, this is for my father

Posts.Content: Hello. Its a very personal decision. AS might be OK in your circumstance with the possible exception of the PSA. If you have a large prostate the PSA might be reasonable. How big is your prostate? If you have a small prostate with that PSA then the cancer might be more significant. AS can include monitoring, diet, meds like metformin and supplements. Some here have made the choice of seed radiation (brachytherapy) and had good results with minimal side effects. Good luck with your decisons. http://www.medpagetoday.com/Hematolo...teCancer/34973

Posts.Title: 56 years old - Gleason 9

Posts.Content: Welcome, What was your PSA number? What is your age? Has your PSA number been going up over time? Any pain or urinary symptoms? We would probably need some more facts to offer concrete advice. A biopsy can determine if a patient has prostate cancer. When I had a prostate biopsy I had to take a laxative first and an antibiotic. There was an enema if I remember. The biopsy involved spring loaded needles which entered the prostate through the rectum. There was a mild sting to it but not big pain. Some people drive themselves home afterward, but a relative drove me home. There was no bad side-effects from my biopsy. The tissue obtained revealed that I had an intermediate prostate cancer. Anyway if your PSA is very high or been going up over time, then a biopsy would be a reasonable idea. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: Thanks for Letting Me Eavesdrop

Posts.Content: Hormone therapy is often helpful whether he has a prostate or not, after metastasis. A med a forgot is Xgeva. Historically, a lot of the old chemo poison type meds were not robust for pca. The newer chemo med Docetaxel / taxotere has helped many. If his PSA is down from hormone therapy, then the cancer is still considered androgen dependent. If the PSA goes up on HT / ADT, then he probably is castration refractory which is worse.

Posts.Content: Welcome. Sorry about the situation. In the USA an MRI probably might not have been done but a biopsy might have been done sooner. If the cancer has not spread to seminal vesicles then with radiation or surgery, he would likely live for many years. The majority of men in such situations have no recurrence at 10 years out. If it has spread to seminal vesicles the statistics are not quite so good. It is hard to comment in detail before you recieve the biopsy results. Prostate cancer is often slow growing and most men who recieve treatment live many years. Good luck.

Posts.Content: About Proton, from what I have read, results are similar to other state of the art radiation devices. Proton is extremely expensive in many cases and requires very good insurance. One type of radiation is SBRT and it sometimes can be given in 5 sessions I think. Brachytherapy radiation has 2 types, permanent seeds or High Dose Rate temporary implants. These also might not require a big time commitment. But as was mentioned, you want the most effective treatment first. Good luck.

Posts.Content: I had standard PSA test at Quest. It only showed <.1 which didn't tell me much. Then had "Post-prostatectomy" PSA test at Quest and it came out to .06 which was good enough for my purposes. Haven't seen itemized bill but it must have been cheap. The tests did require a doctor's written order and I annotated that to have a copy sent to me. It indicated Quest will send copy of results to patient. Getting the doctor's order for the test might be the expensive part. Good luck to you. P.S. I have Blue Cross Quests submits a higher bill and then Blue Cross has a max they will allow for the test. So I get the group insurance price.

Posts.Content: The Gleason score is not very bad. However, the PSA number is not good. It is a possiblity that the patient might need radiation if surgery fails. So radiation might be another possibility for primary treatment instead of surgery. Radiation is delivered as a 1 shot seed insertion or through periodic radiation sessions (as many as 40). I think consulting with a radiation oncologist about radiation treatment might be in order considering the PSA number. What was the prior PSA reading and when was it taken? What is the size of the prostate as this can limit some treatments. Anyway, good luck deciding on a treatment plan.

Posts.Title: Active Surveillance vs. begin treatment?

Posts.Content: If the biopsy was for elevated PSA with no nodule felt on Digital Rectal Exam, then the stage would be T1C I'm thinking. Sounds like you have a fairly mild case from the biopsy stats mentioned except for the PSA. You might want to know the PSA density (PSA divided by prostate size.) Also the PSA doubling time before biopsy if you have that data. There is no real rush since you might live 15+ years without treatment. You could ask for 2nd opinion on biopsy slides. Your thinking sounds reasonable. Some might argue for Active Surveillance which takes a different pychology. Good luck with the decision and treatment.

The hospital stay is short followed by a week with a catheter. side effects vary. The pathologist can look at whole prostate. No symptoms of enlarged prostate afterward. Surgeon can examine area and margins. With CyberKnife more appointments. Small possible risk of radiation burns maybe. I'm guessing the surgery would risk more side effects. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Persistent PSA post RP

Posts.Content: Active Surveilance sounds reasonable. You appear to have the kind of cancer that might get you in 20 to 35 years, if ever. On AS you would want to eat healthy. You would want to compute your PSA doubling time after each PSA test. You can change your mind at a later date. There is also Targeted Focal Therapy using lasers or freezing. It is only available at limited number of sites in the USA. There are a couple of injection therapies in Clinical Trials. NX-1207 is one injection in Phase II trials that seems like it might help. Good luck making the difficult decision.

Posts.Title: PSA 150 and a smooth, hard prostate

Posts.Content: My biopsy 2.5 years ago included an outside pathologist. I only received 1 bill for pathology which was from another city. He was not a preferred provider on my insurance so I had to pay a little extra. I think it was about $450.
Posts.Title: Biopsy Pathology Billing

Posts.Content: Welcome. Stats seem to show you have significant amounts of cancer. I did also but on one side only. Asked the doctor how long I would live without treatment and he told me 10 years, maybe. Surgery and possibly radiation seem to be your best choices. If you have any trouble urinating, surgery should help urnination or nocturia. Seed radiation / brachytherapy is also highly regarded. Prostate cancer is often slow growing. There will also be new treatments coming along in the next few years. With treatment you are likely to live for a long time. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Need help interpreting this positive margin ! Please help !

Posts.Content: Hello. You would think they would check PSA before doing a prostate procedure . Some of these procedures take prostate samples and some do not. e.g. laser When prostate cancer is extensive in the bones, then the prognosis is often not good. Did he get hormone therapy? Where are you from? Early detection through PSA tests and biopsies might have produced a longer life. Good luck.

Posts.Title: New to Forum

Posts.Content: There are urologists who don't mention radiation therapy. You really should see a radiation oncologist and see what they can offer. Brachytherapy /seeds and SBRT often extend life for a long time . Some brachytherapy is done in 1 or 2 appointments. SBRT can often be effective in 5 appointments. These modalities might be optimal for a nervous patient. Good luck.

Posts.Title: My first muster onboard

Posts.Content: Active Surveilance sounds reasonable. You appear to have the kind of cancer that might get you in 20 to 35 years, if ever. On AS you would want to eat healthy. You would want to compute your PSA doubling time after each PSA test. You can change your mind at a later date. There is also Targeted Focal Therapy using lasers or freezing. It is only available at limited number of sites in the USA. There are a couple of injection therapies in Clinical Trials. NX-1207 is one injection in Phase II trials that seems like it might help. Good luck making the difficult decision.

Posts.Title: Enema: Yes? No? Maybe?

Posts.Content: Welcome. There are a few nationally known experts on AS some of whom are oncologists. But many urolgists, don't know much about it. Most are basically trained as surgeons. A patient could probably find out a lot about AS from reading and research. Dr. Dean Ornish did a trial using a veggie diet and some supplements which showed a benefit. Dr. Charles snuffy Smith [should be Myers] wrote a book and has video's about diet. There is a trial, NX-1207 was the injection , which offered an injection into prostate tissue in lieu of other treatments. I am trying for a plant based diet after treatment. I take supplements and metformin. Since your condition is not real severe, you have plenty of time to research the topic. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed 10 days ago, insights sought

Posts.Content: Mike, I guess since your PSA was higher, they are assuming micro mets the radiation would not reach. It might be a statistical decision. Your signature shows surgery in 2013, should it be 2014? Vaom8, Radiation after surgery might work in less than half patients, long term. It varies a lot. Sometimes cancer is just in prostate bed, sometimes it's systemic also. Concurrent hormone therapy might make it more likely to work long term. There are a lot of treatments available with more in the pipeline. Good luck to both of you.

Posts.Title: Prescribed Radiation Therapy after Surgery

Posts.Content: Urology with rectal exams and scopes, etc. is not the most glamorous medical field and many doctors seem kind of crude. Many do DRE's that are kind of aggressive. You could get a FreePSA blood test from your GP. (High is better on this test.) There are other blood tests that are also informative. The chance of complications from a biopsy are low. I got Cipro before and after the biopsy. I would suggest further blood tests at the least. Good luck.

Posts.Title: How do You cope?

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear about the diagnosis. Do you know his PSA history? Did they feel a nodule on the prostate during exam? What area is he living in? The PSA doubling time is an important factor in the prognosis. I hope he finds good doctors. Sometimes the cancer is localized, sometimes it is systemic. They don't always know for sure. Good luck to you both.

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer - Gleason Score of 10

Posts.Content: I'm thinking to have the PSA retested in 3 to 6 months, hopefully using the same lab. The Digital Rectal Exam can find nodules on the prostate. There is a Free PSA blood test as another additional possiblity. There is a newly approved test, Prostate Health Index (phi) that just came out. A urologist would know more about this stuff than a primary doctor. Good luck.
Posts.Title: PSA increase from .9 to 2.1 in one year (40 yo)

Posts.Content: Welcome. What country are you from? Quicker action would have been better. There is no guarantee that surgery will cure you since you seem to have a fairly aggressive cancer. You could end up needing radiation and/or hormone therapy (androgen deprivation) later. Prostate cancer can take a long time to develop. If there is spread beyond prostate, you still could live for a number of years. And there are a lot of good new treatments (expensive) being developed. Good luck dealing with the medical system where you live.

Posts.Title: Newbie: This is not looking good.

Posts.Content: There should be no relation of scalp moles to prostate cancer. They are typically 2 different problems. An infection or iinflammation can cause urinary symptoms. (Men age 20 very, very seldom get prostate cancer. It is usually found after age 40.) Perhaps a course of an antibiotic might help with urinary flow. There is a PSA blood test that is sometimes given. Primary doctors and urologists do a digital (finger) rectal exam to check the prostate. Good luck getting to the root of your problems.

Posts.Title: Scalp mole indicative of prostate cancer?

Posts.Content: I'm sorry for your loss. How old was he? Getting it checked out can mean different things in different countries. There are blood tests like PSA that are not definative. There are needle biopsies that are not perfect but more likely to catch prostate cancer. MRI some places. Some authorities want less screening and some want more. It is possible more stringent screening might have prolonged his life. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: What type of vitamins to use

Posts.Content: Welcome. Sorry you have to be here. Gleason 8 is classified as aggressive prostate cancer. Scores are typically reported as 6 to 10. The Gleason score is the sum of 2 numbers. Bone scan clear is good , looks like no metastisis to the bone. Your account mentions mestasis outside the pelvic area which if correct would not be good. If there is metastisis outside the pelvic area than surgery would not cure. He might be looking at radiation with Hormone Therapy ( androgen deprivation ) added. Hormone Therapy may control symptoms for some time, it varies how long. If he recieves hormone therapy, I hope it works for a long time. There are a lot of new treatments being developed. Good luck to you both. P.S. What is his age and PSA number?

Posts.Content: Welcome. What country are you from? Quicker action would have been better. There is no guarantee that surgery will cure you since you seem to have a fairly aggressive cancer. You could end up needing radiation and/or hormone therapy (androgen deprivation) later. Prostate cancer can take a long time to develop. Good luck dealing with the medical system where you live.

Posts.Title: 300+PSA, still have hope?

Posts.Content: Welcome. I am not a doctor but would guess there is a good chance the high PSA might be from prostate cancer. An outpatient biopsy taking tiny samples of the prostate would be the main test to diagnose. Do you know the size of the prostate? Was there a nodule on the prostate? Do you know your prior PSA test results? What is your age? If it is prostate cancer, many grow fairly slowly. Treatment is often helpful. Recomment you go ahead and see a urologist about a biopsy. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Prostate Patholosist report>>>>

Posts.Content: There is quite a bit of controversy about when it get hormone therapy after recurrence. Walsh and some others suggest there is no hurry to start hormone therapy which works on androgen dependent cancer. Lupron shots for example do not seem to work on androgen independent cancer. I have heard of hormone therapy working for as long as 10 years and as few as 3 months so it varies a lot.

Posts.Content: Congratulations on making the decision. That is tough to make. Were you from the UK? The hormone therapy sometimes causes hot flashes, breast tenderness. weight gain. It varies. The radiation sometimes causes irritable bladder or irritable bowels. Temporary rectal bleeding is a possibility. It varies and can depend on the equipment used and skill of providers. I have no person experience with these treatments myself. Others might tell you more. Good luck.

Posts.Title: had tests

Posts.Content: Welcome. I think Chuck has laid it out for you. The good news is that after treatment you are likely to go more than 10 years without recurrence and may have no recurrence at all. It does vary though. Options are surgery or radiation. Side effects can be urinary problems and ED. Sometimes temporary and sometime long-lasting. Good luck choosing a treatment. There are also a lot of new treatments being developed. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed today

Age.Phrase: the profile that Ray is 66 years old <Z> <Z> <Z>

DoctorRecommended.Sample: Some doctors don't advise surgery after the age of 70 or 75. Seed radiation is usually effective and the side effects are not usually that bad....Do you know the size? Most doctors would not recommend active surveillance with 4+3 Gleason 7. Radiation or surgery might be the most likely options....You certainly have tried the treatments the doctors recommended and have made a real effort. I hope the radiation got it....Most doctors would not recommend active surveillance with 4+3 Gleason 7. Radiation or surgery might be the most likely options. Many prostate cancers grow slowly....Does he recommend a radiation oncologist? Is Active Surveillance possible?...Many doctors might feel that surgery would not be currative. Some might suggest radiation treatments....If you choose surgery, a very experienced surgeon is recommended. Surgery allows examination of the tissue by a pathologist which is an advantage over radiation....Does this urologist do surgeries? Does he recommend a radiation oncologist?...The urologist is not an expert on recurrence after radiation, the radiation oncologist is. Suggest you keep testing to find the nadir over the next year or so....
